ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
GOVERNMENT-LINKED COMPANIES
(Divestment programme)


    1. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Deputy Prime Minister (a) if he will give an update on the Government's divestment programme for Government-linked companies (GLCs); (b) whether the large Government shareholdings in GLCs have hindered their efforts to grow in the region; and (c) whether the Government

Column: 993

has any plans to reduce these shareholdings, especially in companies like Singapore Telecom and DBS Bank.

    The Deputy Prime Minister (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government's programme to divest its shareholdings in the Government-linked companies is progressing smoothly. We conducted the initial public offering of Singapore MRT last year, bringing the Government's shareholdings down from 100% to 62%. The Government also divested Semac and Indeco Engineers completely in 2000 and 2001 respectively. Looking ahead, PSA Corporation and Singapore Power are slated for listing, while the three power generation companies (Power Seraya, Power Senoko and Tuas Power) will also be divested.

    With regard to our GLCs' ventures abroad, many have been successful. PSA Corp, for example, has gone as far as China, South Korea, Middle East and Europe. SingTel has footprints in Asia, including Thailand, Taiwan and India. DBS bank is in Thailand, the Philippines and Hong Kong.

    In some regional ventures, the Singapore Government shareholding in GLCs has been an advantage. It has given the GLCs' partners and host governments confidence that this is a bona fide operation with a reputable, long-term shareholder, which will uphold high standards of integrity and not cut corners for quick returns.

    But not all regional ventures of GLCs have been smooth and successful. Many companies treat certain industries as "strategic" and fundamental to their national interest and economic development. But they are cautious about allowing foreign players to enter or buy into their domestic market, especially players with significant foreign government ownership. In banking, for example, regulators typically apply stringent standards and single shareholding limits. In telecommunications, many countries limit foreign participation in their domestic market.

Column: 994



    Where the Singapore market has substantial and visible shareholdings in a company, regulators, political leaders, the press and local constituents tend to perceive the GLC to be Singapore Government-controlled, operating on an agenda that overrides normal commercial considerations. Such perceptions can unnecessarily politicise and complicate mutually beneficial commercial deal strategic alliances or mergers and acquisitions. From time to time, GLCs, like SingTel and DBS, have encountered such problems in their regional ventures.

    As a policy, the Government does not interfere in the strategic and commercial decisions of GLCs. All GLCs must operate strictly commercially, and are expected to yield proper economic returns. They are supervised by their boards of directors and accountable to all their shareholders, including the non-government shareholders who often own the majority of the shares.

    However, if these perceptions exist, we need to address the issue. In many industries, the scale of economic activity is increasingly global. To be competitive and have growth prospects, companies need to transcend national boundaries, especially in a small economy like Singapore. The recent wave of mergers and acquisitions in industries, like banking and telecommunications, reflects this.

    The Government has stated that its shareholdings in GLCs are not sacrosanct. With very few exceptions, GLCs are in play, free to acquire or be acquired in accordance with commercial dictates. If anybody wants to bid for them, whether the bidder is foreign or Singaporean, friendly or hostile, we will consider the proposition seriously. We cannot afford to take a parochial, xenophobic approach.

    Companies, like SingTel and DBS, are large players in Singapore, but small by world standards. To become significant players, they must, over time, evolve into more than Singapore companies. This is why we have lifted requirement for banks and telecommunication companies to be majority Singapore-owned.

Column: 995



    The Government presently owns 78% of SingTel, and 37% of DBS. We do not regard these as strategic stakes, to be permanently maintained. We are prepared to reduce significantly our shareholdings in SingTel and DBS over the medium term. How this should be done will be studied further. It can be by dilution through a merger, private sale to institutional investors, a SOTUS-type asset enhancement exercise for citizens, or some other means. Any divestment should naturally take place at the right price, and under the right market conditions.

    For SingTel, we will remove the "special share" which gives the Government the right to veto major decisions in the company. Instead, we will meet our national security needs through appropriate safeguards.

    For DBS, we will need to ensure that the Singapore character of the bank is preserved, following any divestment by the Government. It is important that we will be able to rely on the local banks to keep Singapore's financial system on an even keel in a crisis. The Banking Act and MAS Regulations help to ensure that the local banks retain their commitment to Singapore, even if they form strategic linkages or merge with foreign partners.

    First, MAS approval is required before single shareholdings can exceed three threshold levels, 5%, 12% and 20%. Second, MAS requires at least half of the board of directors of the bank to comprise Singapore citizens or permanent residents. This specific requirement may need to be modified, for example, in a merger with another party of comparable size, which is able to contribute to the bank and its continued growth and commitment to Singapore. But even in such a situation, MAS will continue to ensure a strong and meaningful Singaporean presence on the board of the merged entity.

    I hope that this statement of our intentions will dispel some of the misapprehensions about the nature of the Government's shareholdings in GLCs, and give them a freer hand to pursue M&A deals with prospective parties.

Column: 996



    Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh): I would like to ask the Deputy Prime Minister two supplementary questions. The first is that, with regard to the report in the Straits Times that the Department of Statistics is doing a review of the scope and range of GLCs, whether the Deputy Prime Minister is aware of this study and whether this study will be coming up soon. It was mentioned in the Straits Times recently. I am not aware of this until I read it in the Straits Times myself.

    The second question is whether there is a need to do another review of the role of GLCs. I recall that the first review was done more than five years ago. A very comprehensive review was done. Could the review be conducted by a joint committee from both private and public sector representatives since this committee can actually look into the benefits of the GLCs, how their strengths can be exploited, areas of cooperation between GLCs and private sector as well as to give guidelines on how GLCs can avoid future encroachment in the private sector and, finally, maybe even ask the committee to hear complaints, if any, of GLCs' unfair competition versus the private sector?

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think Mr Leong is referring to a study recently done by the Department of Statistics which was aimed at determining what proportion of the Singapore GDP was accounted by GLCs. There was a time inflated number of 60% to something originally. And DOS re-estimated this and came out with some number of less than 20%. I think it was 13% ---

    An hon. Member: 12%

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: 12%. That was the main purpose of the study, just to clarify the figure. The study is completed. It is not ongoing.

    On review of the role of the GLCs, this is something which we have continued to do. It is Temasek's responsibility and the Ministry of Finance oversees this. As we have explained, in nearly every case, GLC's function has to be to operate as a commercial entity. There are cases

Column: 997

where there are social considerations as well as the DBS/POSBank which we have discussed extensively. But even with that, DBS still should have a free hand to operate without being subject to undue impositions. As long as they are operating completely freely and without any hidden Government assistance or subsidy, they should be free to do their business as they think fit. I do not think there should be areas where we push them to go and I do not think there should be areas where we prevent them from going. I know that, every now and then, the newspapers will come out with the story of a GLC which went into the roast duck business. I believe the GLC subsequently sold the roast ducks and the business, but that has not been regularly highlighted in the newspapers.

    But it is not our business to micro manage. They have their business. They know what their focus is meant to be. If they are not properly focused, the shareholders will do something about it. In most cases, the shareholders will include minority non-Government shareholders, in some cases, it is fully owned. Then Temasek has to do something about it.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok (East Coast): I would like to ask the Deputy Prime Minister when are the expected dates of the IPOs for Singapore Power and PSA Corp. At the same time, what is the size of these offerings?

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is a little bit premature to say that now. In the case of PSA, the bankers are now in the final stages of their due diligence work. The exact timing of the listing must be carefully studied because of the uncertain and very difficult market conditions. Members will be aware of how the US market has come down sharply over the last few days and weeks, and the Singapore market has followed it down.

    In the case of Singapore Power, its preparations are not quite as advanced, but bankers have been appointed. I cannot commit to when they would be listed because it depends on circumstances.

Column: 998



    Mr Leong Horn Kee: To follow up from my question, the Deputy Prime Minister said that it is not the intention of the Government to micro manage the GLCs. But will the Government look into GLCs which are not covering non-strategic areas? Are there plans for them to be divested, especially if there are parties out there who are prepared to either invest in them, or acquire them, in areas like the Deputy Prime Minister mentioned about roast ducks and other non-strategic areas?

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: I think the Member means GLCs which are participating in non-strategic areas. Yes, indeed. As I explained in my main reply, the Government is not fixed to hold all these GLCs. In very few cases there are strategic reasons why we want to maintain a stake. In most cases, we are open, and if there is a buyer available who makes us an attractive offer, we will be happy to transact. And in many cases, over a period of time, we would be happy to reduce our shareholdings down below where they are now and, maybe even divest completely. Because the original rationale for building up and maintaining these companies has to be reviewed and may or may not continue to exist. But these are listed companies, so I would not like to speak lightly about what we will or will not do until we have firmed up our plans.

    Mr Speaker: We will allow one last question. Mr Chng.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok: This is a follow up of my earlier question. If the market sentiments are favourable, will the IPOs take place this year?

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, PSA and Singapore Power would not have appointed investment bankers and proceeded with due diligence unless they have very serious intentions. And we have said our intention is to list them. But can we be ready this year? We have to judge the timing. The timing is a tactical decision. If it is not this year, it will be next year, or the year after. But we are not seeing it as a very long drawn-out process.

    The Chairman: Head U - Ministry of National Development. Amendment No. (1). Mr Loh Meng See is not here. Mr Ang Mong Seng.

    Mr Ang Mong Seng (Bukit Gombak)(In Mandarin): Sir, the Government is very concerned about the competition and challenges faced by the HDB neighbourhood retailers, and has established the Retail 21 Development Plan to help them to upgrade and develop their business. A sum of $16 million has been allocated for this purpose.

    On the question of how these neighbourhood retailers could upgrade their management and break out of the difficult situation, may I make the following observations:

    1. Change in shopping behaviour. In the past, when people went shopping, they would have some specific needs in mind. For example, Minister Mah mentioned that in his younger days, when he went to the provision shop to make his purchase, he would already have in mind certain goods to buy, eg, sugar, oil, etc. However, with the changes in time and lifestyles, people nowadays enjoy going to the shopping centres just to look around, without having anything in particular that they would like to buy. If a certain display at the window attracts the shopper, he would go into the shop and

Column: 1000

examine it before buying. On the other hand, if the goods are displayed in a haphazard manner, they will not attract the young shoppers. Furthermore, in the old-fashioned provision shops where the goods are stacked up disorderly, some dishonest customers may take away certain goods and walk out of the shops without paying for them. The shopkeeper may not even notice it. Therefore, these neighbourhood retailers can learn a thing or two from the 7-Eleven stores where there are always a good product mix and the goods are displayed in an orderly and attractive manner.

    2. Changes in shopping environment. One reason why shopping centres could attract the crowd is the comfortable and spacious environment. Neighbourhood retailers can attract shoppers by improving the surroundings of the shopping areas. Chong Pang Town and Hong Kah Plaza are good examples of how retailers got together and worked with the Town Council to improve the shop facades and the general surroundings, thereby making them move spacious and attractive. The Gombak Town project which is underway will be yet another example.

    3. Changes in rental. At present, all shops, whether located in the residential blocks, neighbourhood or town centres, are charged market rental rates. How does HDB determine the market rents? These rents are computed according to the 6-month tender price of the shops. However, two things happen when shops are tendered:

    (a) The "kiasu" tender where the bid is extremely high, for fear of failure to secure the place; and

    (b) The "kiasi" or "afraid to die" tender where the bid is very low for fear that the capital cannot be recouped and the business will die.

    Neither of these should be used as a benchmark for determining market rate rental. A more reasonable computation would be the highest tender rental plus the lowest tender rental, divided by two, eg, $3,000 + $1,000 divided by two, giving

Column: 1001

a rental of $2,000, which is more reasonable. But this market rent should be charged only on shops in the town centres selling consumer and expensive goods, such as watches, jewellery and cosmetics. I am sure Mr Speaker is very familiar with the watch trade. A watch which is sold for $1,000 can bring the shop owner a profit of $100. However, in a sundry shop, a bottle of soya sauce is sold at $1 and the profit is only 10 cents. Therefore, rental for shops in residential blocks or in the neighbourhood should be benchmarked according to the type of residents living in the area. They should be charged a reasonable rental rate to help lower their business costs, so that they can carry on with their business.

    4. Government buy-back package. Some ageing shopkeepers are finding it difficult to continue with their business. They could have been doing the business from a tender age and stuck with it until a ripe old age. They cannot carry on with their business. According to the present HDB regulations, those who want to return the shops to the HDB cannot get any compensation. They would have to fork out some money to refurbish the shops before such premises are returned to the HDB. When the shopkeepers are old, there is no one to take over. Therefore, can HDB change this rule? It should render a helping hand to these shopkeepers. HDB should consider allowing them to return the shops and pay them a sum of, say, $48,000 as compensation, as is the practice under the Selective En-Bloc Redevelopment Scheme (SERS).

    I hope the shopkeepers, trade associations and HDB would consider the above suggestions. I believe retailers in the HDB still have good prospects.

    Dr Ker Sin Tze (Aljunied)(In Mandarin): Sir, the poor business of HDB neighbourhood shops is a problem which has been in existence for a long time. Part of the reason is that their trades, as specified by the HDB, are not relevant to the demands of the market in the present day

Column: 1002

and the shopowners are not allowed to change their trade. As such, they just had to carry on doing their business in very difficult circumstances.

    I think the solutions to this problem are:

    (1) Greater flexibility on the part of the HDB to allow the shopowners or tenants to change their trades; and

    (2) Permission by the Urban Redevelopment Authority to allow those neighbourhood shops in the out-of-the-way localities to change the use of their shops. In places where there are too many shops, resulting in many shops being left vacant, URA should allow them to be used for other activities.

    In any estate, the HDB specifies what trade the shops should be engaged in. It is, of course, good to have a proper trade mix, for the convenience of the residents. However, when the convenience shops, like 7-Eleven and Cheers, come into the neighbourhood, the traditional provision shops could not compete with them. On the other hand, the HDB does not allow the provision shops to change their trade, so they have to just carry on with the same trade, even when there is no longer any demand for such a trade. So, to solve this problem, the HDB should have greater flexibility to allow the shopowners and tenants to change their trade and let market conditions decide the number of various types of business in the neighbourhood shops. The HDB should also help those who cannot carry on, eg, the ageing shopowners, and let them exit by giving them some form of compensation. Only then can the shops in the HDB estates be re-packaged to serve the residents under a new and fresh look.

    Next, I would like to talk about change of use. URA specifies that the neighbourhood shops in HDB estates could only be used for retail business and not for other purposes. This is understandable. However, in some out-of-the-way localities, there are too many shops, resulting in a surplus, and many of the shops could not attract tenants and they are closed throughout the year. If URA could permit these shops to change

Column: 1003

their use and allow the tenants to use them as showrooms or offices, then at least these shops could be fully utilised and it could also bring more life to the housing estates.

    The Government has already allowed those who are involved in the Internet-driven companies to use their residence as an office. Why is it that we cannot allow the vacant shops to be converted to offices and allow the start-up companies to start their business at a lower rent to cut their overhead expenses?

    Another related question is the request of the residents to convert the upper floor of the shops for other purposes. According to the original design, the upper floor of the shops was meant for the shopowners and their families to stay in. By staying on the upper floor, the shopowners will enjoy great convenience in looking after their business downstairs. This was a good conception, but this was 20 years ago. Now, with the changes of time, most of the shopowners have their own flats elsewhere and they use the premises upstairs as warehouse or offices. According to the rules, they would have to apply to the URA for change of use and, very often, it would be very difficult for them to get the approval. My parliamentary colleague, Mr Leong Horn Kee, mentioned during the debate on MTI's budget, that the owners of the shops along Upper Thomson Road applied to convert the second storey of their shops into offices or other commercial purposes, but their applications were refused and the reason was that it would cause traffic congestion. As for HDB, they refused to allow the shopowners to convert the upper floor into a warehouse because the floor was not strong enough to withstand the extra weight of the goods to be stored there. So, using the upper floor for storage would pose problems. But if there are people just working there as an office, would there be additional weight as compared to people living there?

    I hope that URA could reconsider these applications for conversion of use and give them more sympathetic consideration. In fact, URA has approved applications for the change of use by some of

Column: 1004

these premises. However, the approval is valid only for one year. So if they want to carry on using the premises for the changed purpose, they would have to resubmit their application every year. This is time and energy wasting. As a result, the shopowners would not dare to spend money on renovation, because of the uncertainties. So we should allow them to convert the upper floors into offices. This will put the premises to optimum use and allow the owners to save their business cost so as to cope with the uncertainties in the next couple of years.

    The Chairman: I would like to inform hon. Members that the "guillotine" time for this discussion is 3.00 pm. Dr Tan Boon Wan.

    Dr Tan Boon Wan (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, our neighbourhood retailers face difficulties. I join my parliamentary colleagues in expressing our concern, and to urge the Government to help them. I support many of the suggestions made by my colleagues.

    However, no business can survive if the customers do not support them and do not need their products and services. The issues of the management of the shops, and their relevance to the community, impinge upon their long-term viability. They need help with these issues. But to overcome their difficulties, they must want to change; they can help themselves. Today, in many neighbourhood centres, retailers have come together to form merchants or business associations. To help themselves, they can carry out market surveys to determine the needs of the communities they serve. They can get consultants to advise them. They can organise courses to upgrade their management skills and the skills of their workers. They can also organise visits to learn from successful shopping centres.
1.00 pm

    The Government recently unveiled a slew of supports under Retailers 21. I am confident that it will go a long way to assist retailers. However, if retailers want to help themselves, I hope that

Column: 1005

the Government would consider making available this support, both funds and expertise, to the neighbourhood merchants and business associations. If this is possible, this help will be brought closer home. The help can then be specifically tailored to the needs of each neigbourhood shopping centre. By being directly involved, the retailers will be better motivated with a sense of ownership of the support programmes. Training will be more accessible and convenient to the retailers and their workers.

    Sir, I also want to make an appeal to our landlords. HDB has sold many of the neighbourhood shops. Many owners have rented out these shops. I have seen shops that enjoy good business fold. A common refrain is that landlords have increased the rent. There is nothing left for the tenants after that. Landlords should charge a fair market rental that reflects a reasonable return on their investments. Reasonable rental means reasonable cost. This translates into lower prices for the customers. Everyone benefits. The landlord gets a good steady rental, the retailer makes a satisfactory return for his hard work and the residents enjoy fair prices and good service. Hence, I urge our landlords: please do not raise the rent just because your tenants enjoy good business. Tenants go into business to make money. They work hard for their profit. It does not motivate them to work if the fruits of their efforts are being creamed off. Neighbourhood retailers bring convenience and needed services and products to the community. We should help to ensure their continued viability and presence.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok: Sir, I understand that the Government has stopped the sale of HDB shops. In my experience, I see several plus points for this programme to continue.
